active_learning.discussion_prompt: In groups, debate: 'Is pretexting more dangerous than phishing due to its personalization? Use Verizon DBIR statistics (90% breaches involve social engineering) and MITRE ATT&CK techniques to support your position.' Encourage critical thinking on prevention trade-offs.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

Generate 50 high-quality flashcards on 'Pretexting Techniques' (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Security And Risk Management > Security Awareness and Training > Threat Awareness and Prevention > Social Engineering Attacks > Pretexting Techniques). Incorporate: - Research: Pretexting = impersonation via false scenario for info extraction (eweek.com). Key: info gathering, impersonation, false scenario. MITRE ATT&CK: T1591/T1592 Gather Victim Org/Host Info (e.g., business relationships), T1598 Phishing for Info. Sources: MITRE ATT&CK, Verizon DBIR (90% breaches social eng.), eweek.com. - Prior knowledge: Links to phishing/vishing. - Prevention: Verify identities, limit sharing, training. - Learning objectives: [INSERT FULL LIST FROM JSON]. - Scaffolding: [INSERT FULL 4 LAYERS FROM JSON]. - Active learning: [INSERT FULL FROM JSON]. Output ONLY valid JSON array of flashcards, each as: { "id": 1, "front": "Question? A) Opt1 B) Opt2 C) Opt3 D) Opt4", "back": { "correct_answer": "**B) Correct**", "explanation": "Detailed...", "distractors": ["A: Why wrong...", "C: ...", "D: ..."], "bloom_level": "APPLY", "scaffolding_layer": "Layer 3", "active_learning_link": "Discussion prompt" } } Follow flashcard schema exactly: MCQ with 1 correct/3 distractors (protocol: plausible errors, biases, overlaps). Distribute: 20% higher Bloom's. Ensure completeness, real examples, defenses.
